content.description:
The ramp is different and worthwhile, the top moves a bit thoughtful. 

  Diagonal Left up the ramp, then straight up and over the left side of top cap. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
15-25 feet right of the obvious gully, at the base of obvious left-trending ramp. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Intricate thoughtful crimps with slopy footholds.   . . (perhaps crux is getting off the ground). 

  Up staying a bit left of the vague ridge. 

  . . (? Variation project: About ten to twelve feet up, go diagonal left a ways then straight up ?). 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Just Left of vague ridge nine to twelve feet feet left of gully. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Variety of interesing moves. The most fun of the easy routes in this sector. 

  Start up left arete of 5-ft-high rock on right side of gully (or up corner between gully and rock). Step into the gully, and up to its top. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Obvious right-facing inside corner / gully in the right half of the main face, with a 5-ft-high rock on its right. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Some interesting moves. 

  Way harder if much less tall than 5ft 7inch with normal reach. 

  Start up the outside corner / arete about six feet. Next traverse Left on ledge about five feet onto the west face. Up the right side of the face. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
The outside corner between the wider taller main south face and the smaller shorter west (left-side) face. 

  - - > see on this Photo

  . . . . or on this Photo

content.description:
Sustained small crimps. 

  Up through the two small vertical rounded corners. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

content.location:
8-12 feet right from the left edge of the main (south) face, below two vertical small rounded corners mid-way up about three to four feet apart.

content.description:
Nice introduction to slab climbing, first a warmup, then the crux. 

  Straight up the face staying definitely left of gully. Finish up crack (crux). 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Two to four feet left of gully, and a bit right from below dark streak partway up. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
I haven't tried this one yet, so the diffficulty and quality ratings are my current best guess based on other reports. 

  Up to and layback right around roof. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Supposed to be nice climbing, but I haven't tried it yet, so the diffficulty and quality ratings are my current best guess based on other reports. 

  Up left on the ramp, then straight up and over the top cap. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.location:
Under roof on lift side of big inside corner at lef side of the smaller shorter west (left-side) face of this crag. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Sustained thin face climbing. 

  Up to the right one of the two vertical small corners, later move right. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

12-16 feet right from the left edge of the main (south) face, below and a bit right from two vertical small rounded corners mid-way up about three to four feet apart.

content.description:
Nice introduction to slab climbing. 

  Up over the dark streak, staying right of the vague ridge. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  First _possible_ place for Trad protection comes a good ways off the ground.
content.location:
Five to eight feet left of gully, below dark streak partway up. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Thoughtful sequence off the ground, but then the rest is easy. 

  Get onto the lower right part of ramp, then diagonal left to the top. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
content.protection:
For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Falling climber on the first section would likely take a big swing sideways, so need to set up top-rope anchor and conduct the belaying to prevent a fall there from causing harm. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
At lower right of a vague slopy ramp rising right to left. Just left of small rock, or about 15-20 right from 5-ft-high rock which is just right of the obvious right-facing inside corner / gully. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Delicate thoughtful sequence -- too bad it's not longer. 

  Much harder if less tall than 5ft 7in with normal reach (and likely easier for climbers taller than that). 

  Get onto right top of 5-ft-high rock, and up from there, 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

5-ft-high rock on just right from bottom of lobvious right-facing inside corner / gully in the right half of the main face.  

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
Sustained on non-positive holds.   . . Perhaps the "next lesson" in slab climbing for those who have practiced on the two routes to its right? 

  Start on the right side of the ridge, then up the vague ridge to the top. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.

Vague ridge nine to twelve feet feet left of gully, a bit left from below dark streak partway up.

content.description:
Short thoughtful crux much harder than the rest, but not necessarily fun. 

  More interesting to start left of the gully, then move up into it, then up the gully to the top. 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.

For ideas how to set up Top-Rope, see description of this West Terrace sector. 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Obvious gully roughly in the center of the main wall. 

  - - > see on this Photo

content.description:
The west-most of the sunny view platforms of Powerlinez. 

  Interesting slab climbing at a wide variety of difficulties.   . . (Perhaps see how far you get on the progression from easier to harder). 

  Top-Roping: Setting up a top anchor likely requires a non-short static line, say like 50 feet (longer for routes on right side).  

  A short way to get access from base to top is to walk 70-90 feet Left (NW) along base and see gully which starts up easy scrambling, but finishes with a short sequence low-5th-class.   Otherwise access between top and bottom can be difficult or time-consuming. One idea is to send some member(s) of the party (carrying anchor-building equipment and the belay rope) to the top of the cliff (via the Boulder Rd) -- while the others go to the bottom of the cliff. After building the top anchor, the top members can rappel down to rejoin the others. If everyone arrives together at the bottom, it's a long walk around either the northwest or the southeast ends of the Rock Dojo cliffs and rocks. 

  . . (This cliff was called "Buttrest Buttress" in the old print guidebook). 

warning: Loose rock is still a concern here. Belayer or other members of party should not stand anywhere near underneath the climber.
